title.rendered: Scam: Claro denounces ‘false advisers’ on WhatsApp

content.rendered:
WhatsApp continues to be one of the platforms most used by cybercriminals to defraud users, and the modalities are diverse. A statement from Claro Peru alerts its customer base to a new form of fraud, in which Scammers use a false identity to target users as “service advisors” of the company.

According to Claro, “cases have been reported in which users who have some type of debt with us have been contacted by ‘false advisors’, stating that thanks to a supposed ‘loyalty campaign’ they will be able to cancel their debt by paying only between the 20% and 25% of it”.

The company has confirmed that this alternative is not offered through its channels and that it is not a real campaign. For transactions, Claro and different operators offer a series of face-to-face and virtual platforms, in addition to bank payments from apps.

“We regret what happened to the people who have been victims of this type of fraud and we reaffirm our commitment to cybersecurity in all our platforms, processes and transactions,” Claro adds in the statement.

How do WhatsApp scams work?

Typically, these scammers access user numbers that are leaked from databases, and are acquired on Internet black markets. With this base, the criminals launch a “bait” to thousands of users simultaneously to obtain at least a 10% success rate.

Sometimes, scammers use social elements that can cause users to worry or feel anxious, such as a debt due or a service cutoff.

If you receive one of these messages, remember to report it on WhatsApp, by clicking on the contact’s profile picture and entering “contact information”. At the bottom of that screen is the “report contact” option.
